segments.text: Saturday weekend, and he wants to drive everywhere in the world, you know.
I remember what that was like.
Okay, so let's, how'd you get in?
May 1943, I was inducted into the Army.
I had completed four years of ROTC at A&M, and I was waiting, I was in February 1943, I had completed four years of ROTC.
And if I'm not mistaken, I had a straight A in bull techs.
And I was also captain of the basketball team.
And I also applied to the University of Texas Medical School.
And I had gotten a letter saying they were evaluating my application.
They would let me know.
So I talked to A&M.
A&M says, well,
you can stay till you hear from the medical schools.
And my class was called up in February of 43 to go to the Army.
And so I didn't get medical school, so I was inducted into the Army in May of 43.
Fort Sam, and they sent me to Fort Sill, Oklahoma for basic training.
So they wired A&M to give me my commission, which I had earned.
And Colonel Welty, who was a commandant at that time, wouldn't release my papers.
Why not?
Because I had not gone in February.
He was mad at me.
What did he think?
I don't know what he thought, Terry.
You were slacking off or something?
I don't know if I was slacking or what.
But he wouldn't release my papers.
So I had to go through basic training, May, June, and July, and apply to OCS.
Really?
That's right.
Instead of getting a commission immediately?
Immediately.
And so I went ahead.
That cost the government a lot.
It did.
I went ahead and went through basic training as a recruit.
And of course, in the artillery school, a sergeant who was in charge of recruit training recognized immediately that I knew something about field artillery.
So he made me his assistant, acting corporal or something.
So I got some good training and leadership there.
And I got consideration from the sergeant.
Guard duty and all that stuff that they normally put you on.
Anyway, I had to apply to OCS, like anybody else.
And I was accepted.
And they sent me to fuel artillery OCS there at Fort Salem, and I graduated November 11.
Yeah, in 43.
Yeah, 43.
Then I was immediately sent to- Commissioned.
I knew you were commissioned.
Commissioned November 11.
And I was sent to the 8th Armored Division in Fort Polk, Louisiana.
And I stayed with the division until I went overseas.
And when did you go overseas?
September 1944.
And went to England and then we went into the Battle of the Bulge of January 1945.
What was England like when you got there?
Well, it was wet, cold.
We were on a place called Windmill Hill.
We picked up our equipment and we didn't, we couldn't do much traveling.
Went down to Bournemouth, England.
Went to London one day and got off the train and there was a buzz bomb went off a couple blocks away and blew us all down so I got back on the train and went back to
Westchester where we were, Woodmill Hill.
How'd you get along with the British people?
Good, very good.
Got along well.
And then we crossed the channel, went into France, and then we went into the Bulge with General Patton's army.
Yeah, I wanted to talk about that.
Of course this is December 1944.
So when did you first see action?
January.
That's when you first saw action, doing the bulge.
No, it was earlier than that.
It was January the 5th.
Well, early January.
Early January.
Were you called, were you always expected, once you were in England, were you always expected to be shipped over?
Oh, yes.
There was no question about it.
No question about it.
Did they accelerate because of that?
Accelerated, that's right.
Because of the Battle of the Bulge.
That's right.
Okay.
Then the Germans attack in December of 1944.
Right.
And who was your commanding officer?
Who was your general?
What army were you in?
General Devine.
Okay.
It was the 8th Army Division.
General John M. Devine.
He was a West Point classic.
I received from him the first silver star for gallantry in action.
the Battle of the Bows or the Fjallraven.
Okay, now I want you to describe this action.
I've got the little printout here on it, but I'd like you to describe how you won Silver Star.
We were, we were attacking a little town called Nenning, Germany.
And I was with- How do you spell that?
N-E-N-N-I-N-G, Germany.
And it's right where the Moselle River and Luxembourg, Germany and France meet.
Right in there.
And we were attacking a German strong point.
It was a chateau.
And in the town of Ninning, I was with C Company of the 7th Infantry.
And the battalion commander was Colonel Poinier.
And I was with him, and he was directing the fight.
During the night on the jump off some of the infantrymen got hit pretty bad and there weren't any medics around.
So I went back and got the medics and brought them up there and we evacuated.
You drove back?
I walked back.
Walked back to the medics.
They were pretty far back and got the ambulances and everybody to come up there.
And so then
as dawn was breaking, the commander wanted some artillery support, so I went forward beyond the line and directed artillery fire preparation for him to jump off.
And so when he did, the battalion commander went with him, Colonel Pornier, and he got hit.
And so he laid out, we were at the edge of town, and he was sort of a courtyard thing, and the battalion commander
was laying out in the opening.
And two medics went to get him, and they were killed immediately by snipers.
And so we sat there for 30, 40 minutes.
How did you know he was alive?
Well, he would move a little bit.
Oh, OK.
But we knew that the medics were dead.
They were just dead.
You could tell because the bullet hit one of them in the head, and the other hit him just below the neck.
And so we knew they were dead.
And so I kept looking around, and I said, where's the rest of the medics?
And they said, there's no more.
So we got to get Colonel Parneer out of there.
And they said, well, what are we going to do?
I said, here's what we're going to do.
And I ran, and I got him, and I drug him back.
And while doing so, the mortar fire and infantry fire, it was all around us.

pulled him back behind a wall and by that time we were under an artillery barrage and the bricks and everything began to fall and here was a colonel was laying there face up and so I took off my helmet which you don't never do and I put it over his face and then I got on top of his body and then all the bricks fell on my back and so
After that slacked up, then the medics could come.
They could come where we were.
And so they came up there with the ambulance.
And I gave him a couple of morphine shots and marked his head.
Morphine.
That's what we did.
All F-4 observers carried about a dozen morphine syringes with them.
And you break them like these iodine swabs, morphine swabs.
And you used them in case somebody got hurt like current partner.
When you did, you took an iodine swab and you marked a man's head, morphine one or morphine two.
Depends on how many shots you do.
And so they evacuated him.
And I left that position and I went forward again and I directed artillery barrage for about two hours on top of a chateau that was holding us up.
And inside the chateau were better than 500 Germans.
No kidding.
Oh man, we couldn't move.
And so by the time the artillery barrage let up, and incidentally, I directed the battalion barrage, division artillery, corps, and we got army, third army artillery in there.
So you can imagine the artillery fire we were getting.
So you were the spotter for all of them?
I was the spotter.
I was the spotter for the whole army artillery.
And as soon as
We were ready, as soon as the infantry and tanks, the armored tanks, were ready to move off, I ceased fire.
And they moved in and captured this chateau, which was holding up the whole line.
And from then on, they went on in.
Well, Colonel Parney had lived and came back on a cane to direct his battalion many weeks later, and came over and thanked me.
But for that, they gave me the Silver Star.
for gallantry in action.
The oddity of it, Terry, was that my battery commander, who had to write up a citation, put in for a Bronze Star.
And when it got to the division staff, they saw it.
They upgraded it to Silver Star.
And then they made that presentation to me just before we crossed the Rhine River.
General Devine came down, had a regular.
passing review type parade because it was the first Silver Star given in the field artillery, division artillery.
And also, at the same time, I was hit.
I was hit in the face and I was hit in the back, but I didn't stop.
When I went back to get the medics... What were you hit with?
Martyrs.
Shrapnel?
Shrapnel.
When I went back to get the medics, my face was bloody.
And so the medic says, Lieutenant, you better sign in here and
and get some medical aid.
I said, I don't have time.
Well, sign here.
I said, well, you sign my name, Mike P. Kokonos.
So they signed my name, Mike P. Kokonos.
I just took the medics, and blood was all running down my face here.
I got hit right here.
You were lucky.
I was very lucky.
At the time, I got hit.
Were you just skinned across the face?
It was shrapnel.
It went in, and I think it stayed in there.
Because some years later, it opened up and dropped out.
No kidding?
Yeah.
And I was hitting the back.
My back had a score.
Where did it drop to?
Right.
I don't know.
It hung in here.
So you had to have it cut out?
It came out.
You know, it looked like a little...
It fested all the time.
I thought it was a pimple.
It came out.
One day, oh, gosh, about five years later.
So the...
And how about the back injury?
Yeah, it was a shrapnel.
It cut me.
Just cut my back.
I had a map out, and the infantry company commander was showing me how they were going to make this tackle in the chateau.
And we were behind a ditch.
And me and my corporal, radio operator, and sergeant were there.
And the three, the captain and his two platoon leaders, so it was six of us.
The mortars fell right in the middle of us.
I got up, my sergeant got up, my corporal got up, the other three didn't.
They had to carry them out on litters.
The company commander got killed, and the other two were just severely wounded, seriously wounded.
So that's when I got hit, and that's when I went back and got with the battalion commander, and he was telling me what they were doing.
But I was very lucky.
No kidding.
Oh, just.
Probably lucky.
Oh.
I don't know how the good Lord, I guess, stayed with me.
But after that, I crossed the Rhine River with the So tell me, before we go across the Rhine and move up, first I'd like to know a little bit about a forward observer's duty, exactly what you did.
You were a lieutenant.
How many people did you have on your staff?
How did it work?
Tell me how it worked.
Fort observer is the artillery observer.
He directs the artillery fire for the infantry or the tanks.
And his job is to stay with the company commander of the infantry.
Wherever he goes, that's where he goes.
If the company commander says, okay, artillery observer, my first platoon is making an attack.
He needs artillery fire.
You go where that platoon is making the attack.
Mm-hmm.
And so.
So you're always in the action and you're always calling in the gunfire.
Gunfire, always calling artillery gunfire.
Couple of times I'd look up and the infantry was behind me because they felt they ought to move back for some reason or another.
And I'm sitting there directing artillery fire on a tank or a bunker or machine gun and being sniped at.
And so the artillery observer, and what they'd do, they'd send us up for four or five days
and didn't bring us back.
The artillery would.
And either we rested or we flew artillery fire from the L-5 or L-19 observation plane, which I hated.
Didn't like it at all.
Yeah, I didn't like that at all.
I'm not much of flying in those days anyway.
But the artillery observer stayed with the infantry or armored.
Or the tank commander.
Now, if you're a tank commander or observer, which I did once or twice, you rode third in line.
Or the fourth.
You're the fourth in line.
The other three are armored people.
And the artillery observer is the fourth one in line in his armored tank.
But I always had a jeep.
And I had a sergeant, a corporate radio operator, and a jeep driver.
That was it.
And I had an armored...
So there wasn't anybody with a machine gun or anything?
Oh, no.
Oh, no.
I had to depend on the infantry to protect me.
Oh, no, we didn't have any security people at all.
Besides the radio, did you carry arms?
I carried a carbine, and then I got rid of that and got me one of these what you call a grease gun.
It was a submachine gun.
Oh, I see.
I carried that.
And then later on I got rid of that and it got to be cumbersome, so I got me a Luger, which I know I shouldn't be wearing a Luger, because if I ever got captured they'd shoot me immediately.
But my car, my... Why is that?
Because they knew it was a German Luger and they felt that I must have got it from somebody to get it, see.
So this was a talk, you know.
My crew followed me wherever I went and I had an armored, I had what we call a half track, also had all the radio communications in it.
I would go forward of my radio operator and string a line and I would talk to him by phone and he would relay the commands back to the artillery, fire direction center.
And they went through battalion, and they would direct the artillery for me.
I'd give the commands.
And what I learned at A&M in artillery is what I used in combat.
Oh, yeah.
I was delighted firing artillery fire, what I learned at A&M.
Because I got a refreshing of it when I went to the field artillery school.
What I learned at A&M was a foundation for my artillery firing.
Okay, now let's go back to the Rhine again, and oh, I want to ask you another question dealing with this.
And that is, did you ever see, meet, or form any opinions about the great generals of the WWII, Patton, Bradley, and Eisenhower?
Yeah, Patton, you know, I thought was great.
In fact, he drove up in the area where we were.
Did you see him?
Saw him.
Talked to him, told him he shouldn't be up here.
And he left.
And he wanted to know where I was from.
I told him, Texas A&M.
He says, great school.
Did he?
Yeah.
We wanted him to leave because he would draw fire.
We didn't want to be fired upon.
If the Germans found out he was in the area, man, they'd send the Air Force over.
And then Bradley, of course.
What did you think of him?
I liked him.
I thought he was great.
What did you like about him?
Just his bearing, just his confidence, the way he talked.
I think he's a great American.
I really do.
Did you ever see that movie, Patton?
Sure did.
Oh, yeah.
What did you think of that?
Well, at times I thought they kind of overdid the slapping incident.
I don't think that was as bad.
Of course, I wasn't there to see it.
But I'll tell you one thing.
If you went from the 3rd Army area to the,
Seventh Army area.
You knew that you left the Third Army by the discipline and by the dress and by the way they maintained themselves.
And of course, after that, we went to the Ninth Army, General Simpson.
And General Simpson was a great general, too.
But not as great as Patton.
I thought it was just outstanding.
What did you think of Bradley?
Bradley was great.
Oh yeah, I liked Bradley.
We needed Bradley.
He was one of those GI children.
Is that what the troops thought at the time?
Or is that just a label that some pressman gave them or something?
No, no, that was at the time.
Bradley was known as a low profile type, smart, looked after the men.
Well Patton did too.
Patton looked after his men.
shoot, because he was more flamboyant.
Yeah, for sure.
Yeah.
My general, Devine, was a small man, quiet.
I was directing artillery fire over the Ruhr River before we got to the ride.
And I was in a building on the third floor, looking behind a brick wall.
The Germans were 300 to 500 yards across the river, dug in.
And I knocked a gun out.
And so the Germans come out from their hold, and they unscrewed the barrel of the gun.
They unscrewed and put a new one in there and then thumbed their nose at me.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
And Devine was up there.
General Devine was behind me, and he tapped me on the shoulder.
He says, coconuts?
What are you going to do about that?
I said, I'm going to knock that damn thing out in a minute.
It was in Stars and Stripes.
Did you?
Yes, we did.
We knocked them out, but then we moved.
During the night, we moved to...
They didn't shoot at you?
All the time.
Oh, yeah.
They were trying to shoot.
They were trying to knock off your observation point.
They knew I was somewhere in those buildings, but they didn't know where.
They knew it.
Oh, yeah, they were shooting me all the time.
And Devine kind of left, so he left.
And I'll tell you an interesting thing.
I just thought about it.
On the Ruhr River...
And I guess Devine was there, and then he left.
The next day I got a call to come see General Devine and bring your crew.
So I took my crew.
Well, General Devine had to go to Army Headquarters, so he wasn't there.
But his chief of staff says, you and your crew are going to Paris for five days.
I said, what for?
He says, the general said to give you a five-day pass to Paris, as you are.
and to make a report on it when you get back.
So we went, as we were, just, you know, hadn't shaved a couple of days, dirty, filthy, really hungry.
So we jumped in three quarters of a ton, and we took off for Paris, and it took us about 18, 20 hours to get there.
And we got there at the hotel.
They were waiting for us.
No kidding.
Yes, and you were...
He set it up for us?
Oh, yeah, he set it up for us.
I also thought you were great.
And they gave us new clothes.
They gave us a steam room.
And, of course, we bathed and shaved.
And then we went downstairs and they had a table laid out for us.
They said, this is what we're going to do for the first night, and then after that you're on your own.
So, of course, we played in Paris for three days, and then the fourth day we went back.
So when I got back,
Had to make a report.
Said, how'd you like Paris?
Oh, it's wonderful, boy.
Just crazy about Paris.
Said, well, how do you feel?
I feel like staying in Paris.
Yeah.
Said, do you feel the same way now that you did before you left?
I said, no, different.
I don't feel the same way.
Before I left, I was ready to fight.
You know, I'd do anything.
But now, since I've had this five-day period here of rest in Paris,
I got a different feeling about combat.
And what was it then, your feeling?
Then?
What was that different feeling?
Feeling scared, didn't want to go back.
And so then I said, okay.
So they didn't do that anymore.
Too much to lose.
Yeah, that's right.
Exactly.
They didn't, they cut that.
See, they were going to take different groups, different sections, and send them to Paris.
And they cut it.
I told them not to do it.
I said, don't do that.
If you want to arrest a guy, pull him back for a day or two and put him behind, right here behind the lines.
Don't take him out of this environment.
If you take him out of this environment, you lose all the continuity of fighting and the continuity of warfare.
And you throw him in a different world, and he comes back, and he's all screwed up.
And that's what happened to us.
My sergeant and them, they wanted it.
ready to go into combat.
I said, man, we got to go.
We got a job to do.
And that's where my A&M training came in.
Had a job to do.
Even though I wasn't acclimated to doing that again, do it like I did before.
But I said, we have a job to do.
We got to do it.
And my A&M training just says, do it, period.
And it took me, to tell you the truth, I guess it took me, hell, I never got over it, I guess, you know.
But describe Paris during that time.
When was this, January 45?
Right.
Oh, it was great.
About the first February of 45.
Oh, it was, everybody was happy and having a big time.
Americans, so you walk down the street and everybody wanted to buy them a drink.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
The girls were all over you.
Incidentally, I was single at the time.
My wife can't fuss that.
But, oh, yeah, they were very,
grateful for the Americans.
Couldn't do nothing wrong.
Wanted to take you out and feed you and wine you.
Oh yeah, going to a bar and people just all over you.
But I got back into combat and crossed the Rhine River after that and I was all right.
I crossed the Rhine River and I was the only artillery observer, only man in the 8th Army Division that crossed.
The rest of them sitting back supporting.
You were just out there all by yourself?
All by myself.
I was with the 75th Division.
I was there.
And everybody else was on the other side?
The other side.
Crossing Orion was like crossing the English Channel.
It was an invasion.
It was just as wide, I believe.
God, they smoked it all up.
And we crossed.
And I had to direct the artillery fire for the 75th Division.
We were supporting them.
And I was the only 8th Armored Division man to cross the river.
Everybody else was back poised, ready to go.
Then they crossed at Wessel.
So in other words, they put you over first.
Right, as the artillery observed.
I was selected, which I didn't want that honor, to go with the invading elements for the 8th Armored Division.
Yeah, we got a history that tells all about that.
But I didn't want that honor.
They could have given it to somebody else.
But it crossed the Rhine, and then we got into the rural.
Well, how was the fighting at that time?
It was pretty rough.
The rural pockets, see, we had rural pockets.
The Germans were trapped.
And boy, they were suicidal.
They wanted to get out.
So we did get the word.
The division, after the 8th Army Division crossed, and we were fighting, they got the word to let Darmstead, to let
an opening so the Germans could get out.
Because it would have been suicide for everybody.
So they opened the pocket up on the east and let them move back.
Yeah, let them move out of there.
But it didn't demand surrender.
They wouldn't surrender.
They wouldn't surrender.
They didn't surrender.
They wouldn't surrender any time, except right the last on the Elbe River, just before we got to the Elbe, they started surrendering.
and they wanted to help us to go fight the Russians.
But the rear pocket, we hit a bank in Darmstadt, Darmstadt, and money all over the place, German Reich money, and direct and artillery fire, and we just kept going.
Once you got into Germany,
How did the German civilians treat you?
Did you ever even notice them?
They didn't really notice them.
They didn't pay attention to them.
If they went through a town and they had white flags flying, we just kept going.
Yeah.
It was the Hitlerjugend that gave us a lot of trouble.
Oh, they did?
Oh, yeah.
Would you explain that?
Well, they wouldn't, they would, like we took one town to Hilton, they wouldn't.
Anyway, we secured the town.
But the Hitlerjugend were all stuck up in the buildings, and they kept fighting.
They wouldn't give up.
In fact, they hit one of our lieutenants in the armory.
He was riding on top of his tank.
They hit him with a Panzerfaust.
That's a bazooka right in the back.
And they were like, we weren't fighting.
He was just riding.
We thought the town was secure.
It's like terrorist type thing.
And where we went, the Hitlerjugend just fanatically fought and fought.
They wouldn't quit.
They wouldn't give up.
And the war was over, almost.
And how old were these kids?
In fact, when we got to the Elbe River, they turned us around and put us in the Hearts Mountain to dig out the Hitlerjugend kids.
And we would capture them, and they were 14, 15, 16 years old, like my little son Christopher, 16 years old.
They wouldn't quit.
They just kept fighting.
Now, toward the end of the war, you were assigned to occupation duty.
Yes.
Tell me about that.
This is when?
They surrendered in May of 1945.
Okay, they surrendered.
They sent us to Czechoslovakia.
8th Armored Division.
We went there not as occupation but as liberate.
And so we stayed in Czechoslovakia until August or the middle of July and they moved us.
They sent the 8th Armored Division home and I was sent to the 26th Division in Austria and that's where we occupied the country.
And I was in charge of what they call the Cumberland Displaced Person Camps in up Austria, near Gmunden, near the Sea of Gmunden, or the Lake of Gmunden.
It was right outside of Lenz, Austria.
And we had three displaced camps, DP camps, displaced person camps.
And my job was to take care of them, feed them, clothe them, delouse them in reverse order, and put them in boxcars and send them back to Russia.
These were all Russian displaced people.
They were all Russians.
All white Russians.
And my job.
Were they former civilians or military men?
No, they were civilians.
These were civilians.
They were lucky then.
They were in the slave labor camps.
Oh, I see.
Okay, so these people were in a slave labor camp because of Hitler.
Of course, that's right.
And they were white Russians.
Does that mean anything?
No.
It means that the communist Russians wanted them back and just continue what they've been doing, slave laborers or what.
And my job was to get them on boxcars and send them back, which was terrible.

they knew it they knew they knew they were going to go to Siberia or kill get killed they knew it but she has my A&M training again it's my job and as much as I I did the best I could to make it comfortable for them fed them took care of them I would imagine they were in really poorly poor physical condition malnutrition by the time you got a hold of them weren't they they were terrible really skinny skinny and
undernourished, but we fattened them up pretty good.
We fed them good, gave them good medical treatment.
And how many were in each of these three camps?
There's a hundred thousand of them.
A hundred thousand and you were in charge of those?
I was in charge of them.
Of all hundred thousand?
Of all hundred thousand.
And what was your rank by then?
I was the first lieutenant.
In charge of a hundred thousand displaced people.
That was a heck of a lot of responsibility.
It was.
It was.
Why didn't they?
I would imagine that they would have taken somebody of higher rank.
Oh, I would think so too.
In fact, they had a lieutenant colonel who was in charge of it before I got there.
Oh, incidentally, I got a battlefield promotion.
I forgot to tell you that.
In the Battle of the Bulge.
I got promoted from second lieutenant on the field of battle to first lieutenant.
See, there was no rank for my job as a first lieutenant.
And so the general came up, Devine came up with,
and they promoted me to first lieutenant.
Is this after you got the Silver Star?
It was after the Silver Star.
It was cited just like a citation.
They had to write up a citation like they would the Silver Star, why they promoted me to first lieutenant.
I know we're off the subject for a minute, but it was because I was up for
three or four days without food and water and direct an artillery fire line drive to the rural river or to the Rhine after the Battle of the Bulge.
Without food and without water?
Yeah, well, we had canteen without rest, without sleep.
For three straight days?
Three straight days.
Why didn't they give you another medal?
No.
That's usually what the military does, isn't it?
Instead of a promotion?
Well, let me tell you, Terry.
I wasn't going to bring that up, but we were in a battle after the bulge, and it was about two weeks later we were in a battle.
Which one, the Ardennes?
This was later than the Ardennes.
It was on the way to the Rhine, near Muechen-Gladbach.
I had a very dear friend who was the armored artillery observer.
He's the guy who rode in the fourth tank.
And so my infantry company was held in reserve that was in this fight.
And so they were ready to go any time.
So rather than stay with them, I went on up to the front to see how Bill Hamner was doing.
He's Lieutenant Hamner.
And he was in the fourth
and they were fighting a battle with the 81 millimeter mortars.
And when I got up at this farmhouse where the infantry commander was, the battalion commander, I said, y'all seen Lieutenant Havner?
He said, oh yeah, haven't you heard?
I said, no.
He said, look across the road.
And that was about like looking at that house over there, looking across the street and looking at that house.
He said, and his tank was smoldering.
See, that's Lieutenant Hamner.
I said, well, where in the hell's Bill and his crew?
He says, we don't know.
I said, where are the medics?
He says, they can't get over there.
That street right there is just full of fire.
I said, oh, come on now.
Somebody's got to go get them.
Nothing we can do about it.
Every time we get out there, they riddle the street with mortar fire or 81s or machine gun fire.
He says, you can't get across there.
I said, the hell you can't get across there.
I'll show you how to get across there.
And I went across that field of fire and found Hamner in the ditch.
Weren't they shooting at you?
Yeah.
They were shooting all around me.
And found Hamner.
What kind of ammunition?
Machine guns?
I don't know.
It was mortars and everything.
The mortars were just popping.
But I ran across that ditch, and I found Bill Hamner in the ditch.
He had been thrown from the tank?
He had crawled out of the damn tank, and I said, BAM!
And he had taken his helmet and put it over his face.
He was conscious.
And I flicked his hand in the back.
I said, Bill!
He said, oh, you goddamn Greek, where in the hell you been?
You know?
Yeah!
He said, where in the hell you been?
I said, what's the matter, Bill?
He said, you're about to make me cry.
He said, he said, goddamn, I've been waiting for you.
He says, them son of a bitches are not doing nothing for me.
I said, okay, I'll take care of you.
He says, oh, I don't think I'm going to make it.
I said, oh, yeah, you will, Bill.
We were good friends.
We were in training in Fort Polk.
I said, where's Sudie and Corporal Hannigan?
He says, I don't know.
I said, okay.
So I put this helmet back on him, and I took off my belt, and his leg was just shot up.
And I took my belt off, and I put a tourniquet because he was bleeding.
And I took off my first aid pack, and we had penicillin.
So penicillin did real good.
And I said, just sit still, Bill.
So I crawled around the tank, and I found Sergeant Sudie.
And I took his leg.
His left leg was shot.
And I took his belt off and put a tourniquet on there.
And then the other carpal was shot in the chest here.
and a couple other places armed, and he was pretty well shot up.
And I took my morphine syrettes out, and I administered morphine to each one of them, and then marked their heads.
And then I said, look.
And I pulled them, and pulled them behind the tank to where the Germans couldn't hit them.
I said, just sit right here.
He said, I'll be back.
And so Bill was the most crucial, seriously hit one.
I didn't know what I was going to do with him.
And how the hell I was going to get him out of there, because I couldn't carry him across that road.
Because hell, we would all be killed.
So I stood over there, and my battery commander, Lieutenant Kuntz from Purdue, he came up to the farmhouse.
And I could see him.
I said, Kuntz.
Where you at?
I said, I'm over here in this ditch.
I says, go get the Jeep and back it down the road and back it as fast as you can.
And I'm going to pick Bill up, and I'll get him on the Jeep.
And then you take off.
OK.
So he got my Jeep.
How could he go down that road with all that fire?
Well, see, where the tank was.
Was below?
Was down kind of a little dip, and there's a little hill.
Oh, I see.
See, a little hill.
And once you got behind that hill, then the Germans could hit you.
But when you got behind on the other side, they couldn't see you.
I see.
But the tank was sitting right at this little convex thing.
And so he goes, and he gets the jeep, and he backs it.
We were hand signaling each other.
And I said, come on.
And so he backed the jeep up, my jeep.
And when he did, I picked Bill Hamner up, who was six foot and weighed about 165 pounds.
I picked him up and threw him back of the Jeep.
And when he did, he grabbed the tire.
And I said, hold on to the tire, Bill.
And I said, Koontz, take off.
And Koontz took off.
And the German mortar was just right behind him.
Oh, and I'm sitting there in the ditch watching all this, you know.
So he'd take off, and so the other two listening men were sitting there.
I said, how in the hell am I going to get them out of here?
They were hit pretty bad.
So it was getting dark.
So I said, okay, we'll wait until dark.
We'll get the medics to bring the litter over.
and we'll put you on it and shun off."
That's what we did.
It didn't take long, about 20-30 minutes it got dark.
I was afraid Bill would bleed to death, that's why we had to get him out.
So we got the two men over there and the medics took them back.
I stayed and directed artillery fire on the Germans.
Coontz takes Hamner back, and Hamner passes out, and they get him in the evacuation line, and they get him all back to England.
They gave Coontz the Silver Star.
Really?
Yeah.
And the battalion commander came to me.

See, it didn't bother me until the battalion commander came up to me and says, well, we would have given you the Silver Star because we understand what you did and everything, but you already had one.
I said, oh.
I said, I wish you hadn't have told me that, Colonel Dawson.
His name was Dawson, Colonel Dawson.
I said, well, you had one.
We'll just pass it around to somebody else.
I said, well, I said, well, the Army, I said, the Army's not that hard up for Silver Stars.
But anyway, you know, you're talking about medals, not getting the medal.
They gave Kuntz the medal.
And it's written up there.
Did he live?
Oh, yeah.
Hamler lived.
And he came back, and half his leg shot off.
And he came to Beaumont, Texas.
Came to see me about 1953.
Catherine and I just got married.
And he stayed with me for a while here.
And he went to Detroit.
I mean, to California.
He's living in California now.
We haven't corresponded in a long time.
But he lived, and he came, and he says, what's the name of your paper here?
I said, Beaumont Enterprise.
So he went down to the Bowman Enterprise and told them the story.
And they had a big write-up in the paper.
Oh, yeah.
But Hammer was quite a guy.
I've forgotten all about it.
That's a fantastic story.
Yeah.
When you said about metal, that reminded me of this.
It's in our 8th Armored thing.
Well, and was it right after this experience that they gave you the battlefield promotion?
Did this have anything to do with that?
No, no.
This was after my battlefield promotion.
That's what prompted me to give you the story, because you said I should have got a medal for the battle.
Right.
Yeah, I should have got a medal for that, I guess.
But no, I got the battlefield promotion right after riding the bulls with...
Colonel Poirnier right after that.
And that one, now explain that.
That was for being three days.
Yeah, without resting and directing the infantry column.
How could you stay awake?
I don't know.
I'd nod, you know, during the day or something.
But I was busy, you know?
Yeah, right, continually.
Yeah, I didn't realize it.
I was busy all the time.
But Hammer lived.
Sergeant Sooty died.
And the other corporal lived.
Soon he died, though, several years later.
He never got over his complications, began to sit in.
He got torn up on the inside.
And he never could really take care of it.
About like Brady's head, you know.
He had bullet ricochets.
But Bill lives in California now, living in good shape.
Then we went on to the Rhine River and we crossed the Rhine, went into the Ruhr Pocket, then we went into the occupation.
